text.b: Subject: Comparative Trip Generation Analysis for Proposed McCandless Mixed
Use Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: In response to your request, TJKM is pleased to provide a trip generation comparison for the
proposed McCandless Mixed Use Development at Great Mall Parkway and McCandless Drive in
the City of Milpitas. A detailed final traffic impact study dated November 4, 2011 was completed
for a proposed mixed use development consisting of a maximum 1,328 residential units on eight
parcels, as well as up to 92,000 square feet of commercial retail within the four northernmost
parcels closest to Great Mall Parkway. The November traffic study report stated that of the 1,328
residential units, 919 would consist of multifamily units within multi-level podium buildings that
include ground floor retail on the four northernmost parcels (now known as District 1). The
remaining 409 residential units would consist of two- and three-story townhomes on the
It is now our understanding that the project size has decreased in terms of the residential unit
count in both Districts 1 and 2. Specifically, District 1 would consist of 955 multifamily units and
District 2 would consist of 200 townhome units. Commercial retail quantities for the site would
not change. The purpose of this letter is to estimate the expected trip generation for the revised
project size and determine whether the decrease in residential units from the November traffic
study would have any differential traffic impacts.
TJKM developed expected trip generation for the revised project proposal based on San Diego
Association of Governments (SANDAG) trip generation rates contained in the Milpitas Transit
Area Specific Plan (TASP), as well as residential rates consistent with a recent TASP development
traffic study in the Piper-Montague subarea as directed by City staff. These rates are consistent
with those used in the November traffic study. Also consistent with the November study, TJKM
additionally applied trip discounts to the proposed project trip generation that are consistent with
the Milpitas TASP and Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority (VTA) Traffic Analysis
Guidelines in terms of development densities, residential-retail mixed use internal trip capture,
retail pass by, and proximity to rail transit.
Table 1 shows the expected revised project trip generation for typical weekday daily, a.m. peak
hour, and p.m. peak hour periods based on the current development proposal. According to the
table, the revised mixed-use development that now includes 1,155 total residential units is
expected to generate approximately 8,761 daily trips, including 605 a.m. peak hour trips (180
inbound and 425 outbound), and 786 p.m. peak hour trips (506 inbound and 280 outbound) after
all applicable trip discounts are applied.
The above expected project trip totals are lower than the trips generated by the proposed project
assumed in the November traffic study that includes 1,328 residential units. In that study, the
project was expected to generate approximately 9,707 daily trips, including 676 a.m. peak hour
trips (194 inbound and 482 outbound), and 872 p.m. peak hour trips (568 inbound, 304 outbound)
after all applicable trip discounts are applied.

text.b: Table I: Proposed Project Weekday Trip Generation (with 1,155 total dwelling units)

page.text: Sources: Milpitas Transit Area Specific Plan (2007), San Diego Traffic Generators (2002), TJKM (2011)
1. du = dwelling units, ksf = 1,000 square feet, N1/N2 = Townhome Neighborhoods 1 and 2.
2. Parcels 1 through 4 located in District 1, while Neighborhoods 1 and 2 located in District 2.
3. The following trip discounts consistent with the TASP and VTA Traffic Analysis Guidelines were applied:
Parcels 1 through 4 include 13 percent discount for internal trip matching between housing and
retail within each individual project parcel.
b) Neighborhoods 1 and 2 include 13 percent discount for internal trip matching between housing
on Neighborhoods 1 and 2 and retail on Parcels 1 through 4.
Parcels 1 through 4 include 25 percent retail pass by trip reduction.
d) Parcels 1 through 4 and Neighborhoods 1 and 2 include 9 percent fixed-rail reduction for
housing due to proximity with VTA Light Rail stations and/or future Montague BART Station.
It is important to note that since the current project proposal is expected to generate fewer trips
than originally reported in the November study, the November study now represents a
conservative (over)estimate of project-generated traffic. Therefore, traffic impacts are accordingly
expected to be reduced based on the current project proposal. Furthermore, it should also be
noted that all transportation improvements recommended in the November study would have the
same effectiveness under the current project proposal.
Thank you for the opportunity to provide this analysis. Please do not hesitate to contact me with

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: This report presents the results of TJKM's traffic operations analysis for the proposed mixed-use
McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas. This proposed project is located along
McCandless Drive between Great Mall Parkway and the Penitencia Creek East Channel within the
Milpitas Transit Specific Plan Area. Project access is proposed from both Great Mall Parkway and
The purpose of this traffic analysis is to evaluate the potential traffic operational effects of the
proposed project, which consists of a maximum 1,328 residential units on eight parcels and also up
to 92,000 square feet of commercial retail within the four northernmost parcels closest to
Great Mall Parkway. Of the 1,328 residential units, 919 would consist of multifamily units within
multi-level podium buildings that include ground floor retail on the four northernmost parcels. The
remaining 409 residential units would consist of two- and three-story townhomes on the
southernmost parcels. Figure 1 illustrates the location of the proposed project and its vicinity.
Figure 2 shows the proposed McCandless Development site plan.
This report includes analysis of five study scenarios and 11 study intersections (nine existing and
two project-only) that would potentially be affected by proposed project traffic. For the purposes
of this analysis, potential traffic operational effects from the McCandless Development are identified
based on established traffic operational thresholds for the Santa Clara County Valley Transportation
Authority (VTA) Congestion Management Program (CMP) and the City of Milpitas. For study
intersections exceeding these thresholds, transportation improvements are then identified and
evaluated for the potential to bring overall level of service (LOS) back within acceptable thresholds.
The proposed McCandless Development is expected to generate a net of 9,707 daily vehicle trips,
including 676 during the a.m. peak hour and 872 during the p.m. peak hour, after applying all
Currently, all study intersections operate at acceptable LOS based on applicable jurisdictional
standards during both weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours.
All intersections are expected to continue to meet acceptable LOS standards, with the following
• I-880 Southbound Ramps / Tasman Drive (LOS F during p.m. peak hour)
• I-880 Northbound Ramps / Tasman Drive (LOS F during a.m. peak hour)
• Montague Expressway / Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue (LOS F during a.m.

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: All intersections are expected to continue operating under acceptable jurisdictional standards as
under Background Conditions, with the following exceptions:
• I-880 Southbound Ramps / Tasman Drive - LOS F during p.m. peak hour, with increased
average delay beyond four seconds. With the prescribed Milpitas Transit Area Specific Plan
(TASP) improvement of adding an eastbound right turn lane, service levels are expected to
improve to an acceptable LOS E. However, the TASP notes that this improvement may
not be feasible due to potential bridge widening costs. City staff have stated that a fair share
contribution should be made for future signal timing / traffic management improvements at this
• I-880 Northbound Ramps / Tasman Drive (LOS F during a.m. peak hour). However, since
average delay during the a.m. peak hour is expected to increase by fewer than four seconds
(1.7), the applicable LOS threshold is not exceeded and a transportation improvement
• Great Mall Parkway / S. Abel Street – intersection operations are expected to change from
LOS D to E with the addition of project traffic during both peak hours. An improvement of
adding an eastbound right turn lane and southbound right turn lane is expected to improve
operations to LOS D during both peak hours. However, it should be noted that this
improvement is not listed as a TASP mitigation and may not be feasible due to the
proximity of a residential subdivision in the southwest quadrant.
• Montague Expressway / Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue (LOS F during both peak
hours). During the a.m. peak hour, the baseline LOS F condition is expected to continue,
with increased average delay beyond four seconds. During the p.m. peak hour, service
levels are expected to increase from LOS E to F. The Milpitas TASP Environmental Impact
Report (EIR) identified a grade-separated urban interchange as the only feasible improvement
at this intersection. However, the EIR states that this improvement is not fully funded.
An evaluation of 95th percentile (maximum) queue lengths under Background plus Project
Conditions on City roadways directly serving the project site revealed that the following existing
turn pockets are expected to have vehicle queues exceeding existing vehicle storage lengths with
• Great Mall Parkway / McCandless Drive – westbound left turn. Extending the current
vehicle storage length from 230 to 370 feet is expected to accommodate the maximum
expected vehicle queue and can be constructed within the existing Great Mall Parkway
• Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard – eastbound left turn.
Extending the current vehicle storage length from 200 to 350 feet is expected to
accommodate the maximum expected vehicle queue and can be constructed within the
It should be noted that City staff have also indicated that a fair share contribution should be made in terms
of the TASP impact fee and Calaveras Bridge widening impact fee.

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: All intersections are expected to continue to meet acceptable LOS standards, with the following
• I-880 Southbound Ramps / Tasman Drive (LOS F during p.m. peak hour)
• I-880 Northbound Ramps / Tasman Drive (LOS F during a.m. peak hour)
• Great Mall Parkway / S. Abel Street (LOS F during a.m. peak hour, LOS E during p.m.
• Montague Expressway / Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue (LOS F during both
• Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard (LOS F during p.m.
All intersections are expected to continue operating acceptably, with the following exceptions:
• I-880 Southbound Ramps / Tasman Drive - LOS F during p.m. peak hour, just as under
2030 Baseline Conditions, but with increased average delay beyond four seconds. With
the prescribed Milpitas TASP improvement of adding an eastbound right turn lane, service
levels are expected to improve to an acceptable LOS E. However, the TASP indicates this
improvement may not be feasible due to potential bridge widening costs. City staff have
stated that a fair share contribution should be made for future signal timing / traffic management
• I-880 Northbound Ramps / Tasman Drive - LOS F during a.m. peak hour, just as under
2030 Baseline Conditions, but with increased average delay by fewer than four seconds.
Therefore, no transportation improvements are required.
• Great Mall Parkway / S. Abel Street - LOS F during a.m. peak hour and LOS E during p.m.
peak hour, just as under 2030 Baseline Conditions, with increased average delay greater
than four seconds during the p.m. peak hour. An improvement of adding one eastbound
right turn lane, one southbound right turn lane, and one northbound left turn lane is
expected to improve operations to LOS D during both peak hours. However, it should be
noted that this improvement is not listed as a TASP mitigation and may not be feasible due
to the proximity of a residential subdivision in the southwest quadrant. Montague
Expressway / Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue - LOS F during both peak hours, just
as under 2030 Baseline Conditions, but with increased average delay beyond four seconds
for both the a.m. and p.m. peak hours. A proposed grade-separated urban interchange is
the only TASP-identified feasible improvement at this intersection, but is not fully funded.
• Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard - LOS F during p.m.
peak hour, just as under 2030 Baseline Conditions, but with increased average delay by
fewer than four seconds. Therefore, no transportation improvements are required.
An evaluation of 95th percentile (maximum) queue lengths under 2030 plus Project Conditions on
city roadways directly serving the project site revealed that the same existing turn pockets
identified under Background plus Project Conditions are expected to experience spillover
conditions with the addition of project traffic. The same improvements identified under
Background plus Project Conditions are expected to accommodate the maximum queues expected
It should be noted that City staff have also indicated that a fair share contribution should be made in terms
of the TASP impact fee and Calaveras Bridge widening impact fee.
City of Milpitas - Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development
City of Milpitas - Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: Level of service is a qualitative measure that describes operational conditions as they relate to the
traffic stream and perceptions by motorists and passengers. The level of service generally describes
these conditions in terms of such factors as speed and travel time, delays, freedom to maneuver,
traffic interruptions, comfort, convenience and safety. The operational levels of service (LOS) are
given letter designations from “A” to “F,” with “A” representing the best operating conditions
(free-flow) and “F” the worst (severely congested flow with high delays). Intersections generally are
the capacity-controlling locations with respect to traffic operations on arterial and collector streets.
The study intersections under traffic signal control were analyzed using the Highway Capacity
Manual 2000 (HCM 2000) Operations Method contained in the standard traffic software Synchro.
This methodology determines LOS based on average control delay per vehicle for the overall
intersection during peak hour intersection operating conditions. LOS “A” indicates free flow
conditions with little or no delay, while LOS “F” indicates jammed conditions with excessive delay
and long back-ups. The methodology is described in detail in Appendix A.
The operating conditions at the study intersections with minor stop-controlled approaches
(one-way or two-way) were evaluated using the HCM 2000 Unsignalized Methodology, also
contained in Synchro. For two-way stop controlled intersections, LOS is based on and reported
for the worse of the two minor approaches. For all-way stop controlled intersections, LOS is
based on the average control delay experienced on all approaches. The methods rank level of
service on an “A” through “F” scale (similar to that used for signalized intersections) to describe
travel delay and congestion. The methodologies for unsignalized intersections are also presented in
All study intersections fall within City of Milpitas jurisdiction but are subject to different traffic
operational standards depending on whether they are monitored as part of the Santa Clara County
Valley Transportation Authority (VTA) Congestion Management Program (CMP). CMP and
non-CMP standards for the study intersections are described below.
The intersection operational standard is LOS E for VTA CMP intersections located within the
City of Milpitas. Exceedance of this LOS threshold at CMP intersections would occur when the
addition of traffic associated with implementation of a proposed project causes:
• Intersection operations to deteriorate from an acceptable level (LOS E or better) under
Background Conditions to an unacceptable level (LOS F); or
• Exacerbation of unacceptable operations by increasing the average critical delay by more
than four (4) seconds and increasing the critical volume-to-capacity (V/C) ratio by 0.01 or
more at an intersection operating at LOS F under the Current Precise Plan Conditions.
• An increase in the V/C ratio of 0.01 or more at an intersection with unacceptable LOS F
operations when the change in critical delay is negative (i.e., decreases). This can occur if

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: LOS D is the standard for non-CMP intersections within City of Milpitas jurisdiction. For purposes
of this study, the critical minor approach of unsignalized City non-CMP intersections will be
evaluated with a LOS D standard. Such intersections exceeding this threshold will be evaluated for
The study evaluated traffic operational conditions under the following five (5) analysis scenarios:
1. Existing Conditions – this scenario is based on existing 2010 roadway conditions and traffic
counts collected as part of the ongoing Milpitas Signal Timing Project as directed by City staff.
2. Background (Existing plus Approved Project) Conditions – this scenario is similar to Existing
Conditions, but with the addition of approved project trips identified in the Milpitas Transit
Area Specific Plan (TASP) assigned to the study intersections.
3. Background plus Proposed Project Conditions – this scenario is identical to Background
Conditions, but includes additional traffic expected to be generated by the proposed
mixed-use McCandless Development, which consists of a maximum 1,328 residential units
of varying type and density on eight parcels, as well as approximately 92,000 square feet of
commercial retail within the four northernmost parcels closest to Great Mall Parkway.
4. Year 2030 Baseline Conditions – this scenario estimates Year 2030 traffic conditions based on
roadway link traffic volumes and land use projections documented in the Milpitas TASP.
Because the TASP traffic analysis analyzes only 2030 roadway link volumes, growth factors
based on these link volumes were developed to estimate expected 2030 vehicle turning
movement volumes at the study intersections. This scenario assumes background traffic
associated with full build of the TASP, but without traffic generated by the proposed
5. Year 2030 plus Proposed Project Conditions - this scenario is identical to Year 2030 Baseline
Conditions, but includes additional traffic expected to be generated by the proposed
The study focused on evaluating traffic conditions at 11 study intersections that the proposed
project may potentially affect (see Figure 1), selected in consultation with City of Milpitas staff. The
study intersections and their associated traffic controls are:
3. Great Mall Parkway / S. Abel Street (Signal)
4. Great Mall Parkway / S. Main Street (Signal)
6. Great Mall Parkway / Centre Pointe Drive (Signal)
8. Montague Expressway / Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue (Signal)
9. Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard (Signal)
10. McCandless Drive / Street “A” (Retail/Residential Project Driveway just south of
11. McCandless Drive / Street “C” (Residential Neighborhoods 1 and 2 Project Access). Note
that this access has been designated Street “C” solely for purposes of this traffic study.
12. Great Mall Parkway / Retail Driveway (Project Intersection, Right-In/Right-Out, One-Way Stop)
13. Great Mall Parkway / Street “B” (Project Intersection, Right-In/Right-Out, One-Way Stop)

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: Regional access to the proposed McCandless Development site is provided by Interstate 880
(I-880), I-680, State Route 237 (SR 237), Montague Expressway, Great Mall Parkway / Tasman Drive,
Trade Zone Boulevard and Capitol Avenue. McCandless Drive provides local access to the project
site, with a northern connection to Great Mall Parkway at the primary Great Mall entrance and a
southern connection to Montague Expressway and Trade Zone Boulevard. The primary facilities
providing regional and local access are described in greater detail below.
I-880 is a north-south freeway located west of the project site. This freeway extends south to the
City of San Jose and north to the City of Oakland. Near the proposed project, the freeway consists
of six lanes and provides local interchange connections at Great Mall Parkway / Tasman Drive and
Montague Expressway. The I-880/SR 237 interchange is a major interchange to the north that
provides additional regional access to northern and western Santa Clara County.
I-680 is a north-south freeway located east of the project site. This freeway extends south to the
City of San Jose and north to Solano County. Near the project site, the freeway consists of eight
mixed-flow lanes. Further north, I-680 consists of six mixed-flow lanes plus a southbound high-
occupancy toll (HOT) lane north of Calaveras Boulevard (SR 237). Local interchange connections
near the proposed project site are provided at Montague Expressway and Capitol Avenue. I-680
southbound is the primary commute direction during the a.m. peak hour, while northbound is the
primary commute direction during the p.m. peak hour.
Montague Expressway is an east-west, six- to eight-lane divided expressway operating by Santa Clara
County, which runs between the U.S. 101 freeway to the east and I-680 to the west. The roadway
provides limited access to fronting land uses, with primary access via signalized intersections that
include signal timing optimized for expressway traffic progressions. Through the study area,
Montague Expressway intermittently includes directional high-occupancy vehicle (HOV) lanes
(right side curb lane) during peak periods (westbound during the a.m. commute peak period and
eastbound during the p.m. peak period). Montague Expressway connects with I-880 and I-680 via
Great Mall Parkway is an east-west, six-lane divided arterial roadway extending from I-880 easterly
to Montague Expressway. It forms the northern project site boundary. Great Mall Parkway also
bisects the Planning Area. Great Mall Parkway is designated as Tasman Drive west of I-880,
providing a connection to the Cities of San Jose, Santa Clara, and Sunnyvale. Great Mall Parkway
becomes Capitol Avenue east of Montague Expressway, connecting by interchange to I-680 and
continuing southerly through the City of San Jose. Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority
(VTA) light-rail transit (LRT) service is provided along the median of Great Mall Parkway in the
project vicinity in an aerial viaduct, stopping near the project site at Great Mall / Main and
Main Street is a north-south, two- to four-lane arterial roadway parallel to Abel Street extending from
Railroad Avenue (north of SR 237 / Calaveras Boulevard) south to Montague Expressway. This
roadway, located west of the proposed project site, is designated as Oakland Road south of
Montague Expressway. Main Street includes two lanes north of Curtis Avenue and four lanes with a
two-way left-turn lane and bicycle lanes south of Curtis Avenue.

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: Abel Street is a north-south, four-lane arterial roadway extending from Milpitas Boulevard
(north of SR 237 / Calaveras Boulevard) south to Main Street (south of Great Mall Parkway).
This roadway is located west of the proposed project site. The section of Abel Street between
Corning and Curtis Avenues includes four travel lanes plus a two-way left-turn lane.
Milpitas Boulevard is a north-south, four-lane arterial roadway extending from the Milpitas-Fremont
City limit line southerly to Montague Expressway, where it terminates east of the proposed project
site. Milpitas Boulevard is designated Warm Springs Boulevard north of the City/County limit.
Trade Zone Boulevard is an east-west, four-lane minor arterial roadway located south of the
proposed project site. It forms the south leg of the Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive
study intersection, providing the southern gateway to the project site.
Centre Pointe Drive is a northwest-southeast, two-lane collector roadway connecting Great Mall
Parkway with Montague Expressway. The roadway is located immediately east of the proposed
project site and forms the south leg of the Great Mall Parkway / Centre Pointe Drive / Mustang
Drive intersection, which serves as an entrance to the Great Mall.
McCandless Drive is a north-south, two-lane collector roadway that currently includes a two-way
left-turn lane through the project area. It will provide primary local project access to Great Mall
Parkway and Montague Expressway. The Great Mall Parkway / McCandless Drive intersection
provides the primary entrance to the Great Mall.
The proposed McCandless Development site is very well served by public transportation. The
Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority (VTA), which operates bus and light rail service within
Santa Clara County, runs multiple transit routes through the study area. The Great Mall / Main
Transit Center (TC) is located within one-quarter mile walking distance of the proposed project
site, on the north side of Great Mall Parkway east of Main Street. This multimodal transit hub
consists of an elevated light rail transit (LRT) station above Great Mall Parkway, as well as a bus
transfer facility and park-and-ride lot located on the northeast corner of the Great Mall Parkway /
Main Street intersection. A second LRT station (Montague) is located approximately one-half mile
east of the proposed project site and is elevated above Capitol Avenue. No bus or park-and-ride
facilities are provided at this second station.
The Great Mall / Main TC and project study area are served by VTA bus routes 46, 47, 66, 70, 71,
77, 104, 140, 180, 181, and 321, as well as AC Transit route 217. In addition, the Altamont
Commuter Express (ACE) Violet Shuttle (Route 831) runs through the study area along Montague
Expressway south of the proposed project site. Table I summarizes the destinations, days and hours
of operation, and service headways for the bus routes and LRT line.

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

text.b: Table I: Existing Transit Service Within Study Area

page.text: Notes: *Route 217 = AC Transit Route. All other routes operated by VTA.
Bicycle facilities are classified in three ways: off-street paths separated from auto traffic (Class I),
on-street striped lanes (Class II), and on-street signed routes in which bicycles share the roadway
with other vehicles (Class III). Currently, Class II bicycle lanes are provided on Great Mall Parkway,
Main Street, McCandless Drive, and Capitol Avenue south of Trimble Road within the project study
area. Presently, there are no Class I bicycle paths or Class II bicycle routes designated within the
Traffic Data Service (TDS) collected existing vehicle, bicycle, and pedestrian turning movement
counts in October 2010 during weekday a.m. and p.m. peak periods (7:00-9:00 a.m. and
4:00-6:00 p.m., respectively) at all study intersections except the three intersections along
Montague Expressway. For the Montague Expressway study intersections at Trade Zone
Boulevard, Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue, and S. Milpitas Boulevard, Santa Clara County
staff provided existing vehicle turning movement counts that were taken during the p.m. peak hour
only in September 2010. Based on discussion with City staff, in order to estimate existing a.m. peak
hour turning movement volumes at the Montague intersections, TJKM multiplied the 2010 p.m.
peak hour counts at those locations by a ratio of a.m. to p.m. peak hour counts taken in 2005 as
part of the Milpitas Transit Area Specific Plan traffic analysis. Peak hour traffic count data sheets for
the other eight study intersections are included in Appendix B.

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

text.b: Intersection Level of Service Analysis Results (Existing Conditions)

intersections, as well as current lane configurations and traffic controls. Table II summarizes the
results of the intersection analysis under Existing Conditions. Detailed LOS calculations are
contained in Appendix C. Currently, all study intersections are operating at acceptable LOS during
both weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours.

City of Milpitas – Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development
Existing Conditions Traffic Volumes, Lane Geometry, and Traffic Controls

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: This section details expected traffic conditions at the study intersections under Background
Conditions. This analysis scenario is similar to Existing Conditions, but with the addition of vehicle
trips generated by approved but not yet constructed projects as identified in the Milpitas Transit
Area Specific Plan (TASP). Under this scenario, current land uses on the McCandless Development
parcels are assumed. This scenario serves as a baseline for determining any exceedance of LOS
thresholds with respect to the expected McCandless Development traffic. Analysis of this scenario
is consistent with both City of Milpitas and VTA transportation impact analysis guidelines.

text.b: Background Development Assumptions and Traffic Estimates

page.text: Traffic volumes at the study intersections under Background Conditions were estimated by adding
approved project trips from the TASP to Existing Conditions (2010) traffic volumes. A list of
approved projects within Milpitas city limits is provided in the TASP. Traffic generation expected
from Phase 1 of the North San Jose Development Plan is included under this scenario.
Vehicle trips from TASP approved projects were assigned according to the trip distribution
assumptions contained in the TASP Draft Environmental Impact Report (DEIR) and are shown in
Figure 4. These assigned trips were added to Existing Conditions traffic volumes to generate
Background Conditions traffic volumes. The resulting turning movement volumes, traffic controls,
and lane geometries anticipated for the study intersections under Background Conditions are
shown in Figure 5. The intersection traffic controls and lane geometries are based on the
anticipated TASP roadway improvements under Background Conditions that are listed below.

text.b: Background Roadway Network and Improvement Assumptions

page.text: Under Background Conditions, several transportation improvements are assumed to be in place.
According to the 2009 Comprehensive County Expressway Planning Study, Santa Clara County has
identified the following improvements for Montague Expressway through the project study area:
• Convert the HOV lane on the six-lane portion between I-880 and I-680 to mixed-flow
operations due to operational and safety problems. This project has been completed.
• Widen to eight lanes from Mission College to I-680 and to six lanes from I-680 to
Park Victoria, including various intersection at-grade improvements and I-880 and I-680
interchange work. It is anticipated that right-of-way acquisition would be required to
accommodate the proposed roadway widening. A Final Environmental Assessment/Initial
Study was adopted in September 2002, and according to the 2009 Expressway Study, this
improvement is partially completed and partially funded. It should be noted that the
City of Milpitas recently completed widening Montague Expressway to four lanes per
direction between Great Mall Parkway and Milpitas Boulevard, which was outside the scope
of the County’s planned Montague Expressway Improvement Project.
In addition, the Milpitas TASP anticipates improvements to the following study intersections:
• Adding a fourth through lane for the westbound Montague Expressway approach at
Milpitas Boulevard. This improvement is considered part of the County’s Montague
• At the Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard study intersection,
widen the northbound (Trade Zone) approach to accommodate two left turn lanes, one
through lane, and one right turn lane. Similarly, widen the southbound (McCandless)
approach to accommodate the same configuration as the northbound approach.

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

City of Milpitas – Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development
City of Milpitas – Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development
Background Conditions Traffic Volumes, Lane Geometry, and Traffic Controls

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: This analysis scenario is similar to Background Conditions, but with the addition of traffic expected
to be generated by the proposed McCandless Development.
The proposed mixed-use McCandless Development is located within the Transit Specific Plan Area
of the City of Milpitas. It is situated on eight parcels located on both sides of McCandless Drive
(four on west side and four on east side) between Great Mall Parkway to the north and the
Penitencia Creek East Channel to the south. The two northernmost parcels (1 and 3) are proposed
to have right-in/right-out access from both Great Mall Parkway and McCandless Drive. Parcel 1
would also have full access from the proposed McCandless Drive / Street “A” intersection south of
Great Mall Parkway, while Parcel 3 would have one-way outbound (westbound) access on Street “A”
between McCandless Drive and the proposed Street “B”. Full access for the remaining parcels will
be provided from McCandless Drive. Additionally, the proposed Street “B”, which would parallel
McCandless Drive to the east, will provide a secondary right-in/right-out access from Great Mall
Parkway for the four easternmost project parcels.
The proposed project consists of a maximum 1,328 residential units on eight parcels, as well as
up to 92,000 square feet of commercial retail within the four northernmost parcels closest to
Great Mall Parkway. Of the 1,328 residential units, 919 would consist of multifamily units within
multi-level podium buildings that include ground floor retail on the four northernmost parcels. The
remaining 409 residential units would consist of two- and three-story townhomes on the
TJKM developed expected trip generation for the proposed project based on San Diego Association
of Governments (SANDAG) trip generation rates contained in the Milpitas TASP, as well as
residential rates consistent with a recent TASP development traffic study in the Piper-Montague
subarea as directed by City staff. Table IV shows the resulting trip rates used for estimating trips
expected to be generated by the proposed project.

text.b: Table IV: Proposed Project Trip Rates

page.text: Sources: Milpitas Transit Area Specific Plan (2007), Hexagon Transportation Consultants (2008),
TJKM applied trip discounts to the proposed project trip generation that are consistent with the
Milpitas TASP and VTA Traffic Analysis Guidelines in terms of development densities, residential-
retail mixed use internal trip capture, retail pass by, and proximity to rail transit. Table V shows the
estimated trip generation for the proposed project resulting from the trip rates in Table IV and
applicable trip discounts. As shown in Table V, the proposed McCandless Development is expected
to generate a net of 9,707 daily vehicle trips, including 676 during the a.m. peak hour and 872 during
the p.m. peak hour, after applying all applicable trip discounts.

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

text.b: Table V: Proposed Project Trip Generation

page.text: Sources: Milpitas Transit Area Specific Plan (2007), San Diego Traffic Generators (2002), TJKM (2011)
1. du = dwelling units, ksf = 1,000 square feet
2. The following trips discounts consistent with the TASP and VTA Traffic Analysis Guidelines were applied:
Parcels 1 through 4 include 13 percent discount for internal trip matching between housing and
retail within each individual project parcel.
b) Parcels 5 through 8 include 13 percent discount for internal trip matching between housing on
Parcels 5 through 8 and retail on Parcels 1 through 4.
Parcels 1 through 4 include 25 percent retail pass by trip reduction.
d) Parcels 1 through 8 include 9 percent fixed-rail reduction for housing due to proximity with VTA
Light Rail stations and/or future Montague BART Station.
Trip distribution is a process that determines in what proportion vehicles would be expected to
travel between a project site and various destinations outside the project study area. The process
of trip assignment determines the various routes that vehicles would take from the project site to
each destination using the calculated trip distribution.
Trip distribution assumptions for the proposed McCandless Development were based on the trip
distributions contained in the Milpitas TASP. The assumed distribution percentages are as follows:

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: • 5 percent to/from S. Milpitas Boulevard North
• 3 percent to/from S. Main Street North
• 3 percent to/from S. Abel Street North
• 3 percent to/from Trade Zone Boulevard South
Project trips were assigned to the study intersections according to the above trip distribution
percentages. Figure 6 shows the proposed project trip distribution percentages and resulting trip
assignments at all study intersections. The assigned project trips were then added to Background
Conditions traffic volumes to generate Background plus Project traffic volumes. Figure 7 shows the
resulting traffic volumes at the study intersections under Background plus Project Conditions. The
intersection traffic controls and lane geometries assumed under this analysis scenario are the same
as under the Background Conditions analysis scenario.

text.b: Intersection Level of Service Analysis Results (Background plus Project Conditions)

page.text: The intersection LOS analysis results for both Background and Background plus Project Conditions
are summarized in Table VI. Detailed calculation sheets are contained in Appendix E. All
intersections are expected to continue operating acceptably as under Background Conditions, with
• I-880 Southbound Ramps / Tasman Drive - LOS F during p.m. peak hour, with increased
• I-880 Northbound Ramps / Tasman Drive (LOS F during a.m. peak hour). Since average
delay during the a.m. peak hour is expected to increase by fewer than four seconds (1.7),
the applicable LOS threshold is not exceeded, and no transportation improvement would
• Great Mall Parkway / S. Abel Street – intersection operations are expected to change from
LOS D to E with the addition of project traffic during both peak hours.
• Montague Expressway / Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue (LOS F during both peak
hours). During the a.m. peak hour, the baseline LOS F condition is expected to continue,
with increased average delay beyond four seconds. During the p.m. peak hour, service
levels are expected to increase from LOS E to F.

text.b: Intersection Transportation Improvement Measures (Background plus Project Conditions)

page.text: To address the above expected service levels exceeding LOS standards, the following
transportation improvement measures are expected to be necessary:
• I-880 Southbound Ramps / Tasman Drive (LOS F during p.m. peak hour). With the prescribed
Milpitas TASP improvement of adding an eastbound right turn lane, service levels are expected
to improve to an acceptable LOS E. However, it should be noted that the TASP has indicated
that this improvement may not be feasible due to potential bridge widening costs. City staff
have stated that a fair share contribution should be made for future signal timing / traffic
• Great Mall Parkway / S. Abel Street – with an improvement of adding one eastbound right
turn lane and one southbound right turn lane, service levels are expected to improve to an

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: acceptable LOS D during both peak hours. However, this improvement is not likely to be
feasible. It should be noted that no improvements for this intersection were identified in
the TASP, and this proposed improvement does not modify current signal timing plans at
this intersection, which could be another solution to improve LOS to a manageable level
without widening. Furthermore, this improvement would require widening two intersection
approaches, which is not likely to be feasible due to the proximity of a residential
subdivision in the southwest quadrant. It is also important to note that the McCandless
Development’s expected trip assignments through the intersection would not add to the
specific turning movements proposed for additional turn lanes for this improvement.
• Montague Expressway / Great Mall Parkway / E. Capitol Avenue. The Milpitas TASP EIR identified
a grade-separated urban interchange as the only feasible improvement at this intersection.
However, it should be noted that according to the EIR, this improvement is not fully funded.
It should be noted that City staff have also indicated that a fair share contribution should be made in terms
of the TASP impact fee and Calaveras Bridge widening impact fee.

text.b: Expected Vehicle Queues at City Roadway Access Points

page.text: TJKM evaluated the potential effects of added traffic from the proposed project on vehicle queue
lengths for existing turn lanes on City roadways directly serving the project site. The evaluation
included analysis of 95th percentile (maximum) queues expected with the addition of proposed
project traffic, and results are included in Appendix E. Table VII shows expected vehicle queues for
the turn pockets of project access intersections under Background plus Project Conditions. The
table shows that the following existing turn pockets are expected to exceed available vehicle
storage capacity with the addition of proposed project traffic:
• Great Mall Parkway / McCandless Drive – westbound left turn
• Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard – eastbound left turn

text.b: Table VII: Expected Turn Pocket Vehicle Queues – Background plus Project Conditions

text.i: Improvement: Extend WB LTL from 230 to 385 feet

page.text: Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard

text.i: Improvement: Extend EB LTL from 200 to 350 feet

page.text: Notes: 1) * = free turn, ** = proposed storage length with project
2) McCandless Drive / Street “C” (Project Driveway) - all assumed to be single-lane approaches

text.i: Final Report –Traffic Operations Analysis for McCandless Development in the City of Milpitas

page.text: The following improvements are recommended to accommodate maximum queues anticipated
• Great Mall Parkway / McCandless Drive westbound left turn: Extend current vehicle
storage length from 230 to 385 feet. The existing Great Mall Parkway median has sufficient
length and width to accommodate this improvement.
• Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard eastbound left turn:
Extend current vehicle storage length from 200 to 350 feet. The existing Montague
Expressway median has sufficient length and width to accommodate this improvement.

page.text: This section details expected traffic conditions at the study intersections under Year 2030 Baseline
Conditions. This scenario estimates Year 2030 traffic conditions based on roadway link traffic
volumes and land use projections documented in the Milpitas TASP.
TJKM estimated 2030 traffic volumes for the study intersections using 2030 roadway link volume
projections from the Milpitas TASP. Since there are no 2030 intersection volumes reported in the
TASP DEIR, TJKM developed annual growth factors based on TASP link volume growth between
2004 and 2030 on Great Mall Parkway, Montague Expressway, and adjacent study area roadways.
These factors were applied proportionately to existing vehicle turning movement volumes at the
study intersections to estimate 2030 intersection volumes, which are assumed to include full build
of the TASP. It should be noted that this procedure yielded 2030 link volumes that are less than
originally projected in the TASP. While the application of annual growth factors assume an annual
pace of traffic growth similar to TASP, it is reasonable to assume that 2030 link volumes would now
be less than originally projected given the slower pace of development growth under current
To estimate 2030 Baseline intersection volumes, vehicle trip assignments from the proposed
McCandless Development were subtracted out of the 2030 traffic volumes that assume full build of
the Milpitas TASP. The resulting 2030 Baseline analysis scenario thereby provides a traffic
operational basis of comparison for the proposed McCandless Development traffic.

• Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard (LOS F during p.m.

• I-880 Southbound Ramps / Tasman Drive - LOS F during p.m. peak hour, just as under

• Montague Expressway / McCandless Drive / Trade Zone Boulevard - LOS F during p.m.
peak hour, just as under 2030 Baseline Conditions, but with increased average delay by
fewer than four seconds. Therefore, no transportation improvement is required.

Appendix A – Level of Service Methodology
The description and procedures for calculating capacity and level of service (LOS) are found in
Transportation Research Board, Highway Capacity Manual 2000. Highway Capacity Manual 2000
represents the latest research on capacity and quality of service for transportation facilities.
Quality of service requires quantitative measures to characterize operational conditions within a traffic
stream. LOS is a quality measure describing operational conditions within a traffic stream, generally in
terms of such service measures as speed and travel time, freedom to maneuver, traffic interruptions, and
Six levels of service are defined for each type of facility that has analysis procedures available. Letters
designate each level, from A to F, with LOS A representing the best operating conditions and LOS F the
worst. Each LOS represents a range of operating conditions and the driver’s perception of these
conditions. Safety is not included in the measures that establish service levels.
A general description of service levels for various types of facilities is shown in Table A-I

text.b: Table A-I: Level of Service Description

page.text: Stable flow. Presence of other users noticeable.
Stable flow. Comfort and convenience starts to
The term “urban streets” refers to urban arterials and collectors, including those in downtown areas.
Arterial streets are roads that primarily serve longer through trips. However, providing access to
abutting commercial and residential land uses is also an important function of arterials.
Collector streets provide both land access and traffic circulation within residential, commercial and
industrial areas. Their access function is more important than that of arterials, and unlike arterials their
operation is not always dominated by traffic signals.
Downtown streets are signalized facilities that often resemble arterials. They not only move through
traffic but also provide access to local businesses for passenger cars, transit buses, and trucks.
Pedestrian conflicts and lane obstructions created by stopping or standing buses, trucks and parking
vehicles that cause turbulence in the traffic flow are typical of downtown streets.
The speed of vehicles on urban streets is influenced by three main factors, street environment,
interaction among vehicles and traffic control. As a result, these factors also affect quality of service.
The street environment includes the geometric characteristics of the facility, the character of roadside
activity and adjacent land uses. Thus, the environment reflects the number and width of lanes, type of
median, driveway density, spacing between signalized intersections, existence of parking, level of
The interaction among vehicles is determined by traffic density, the proportion of trucks and buses, and
turning movements. This interaction affects the operation of vehicles at intersections and, to a lesser
Traffic control (including signals and signs) forces a portion of all vehicles to slow or stop. The delays
and speed changes caused by traffic control devices reduce vehicle speeds, however, such controls are
The average travel speed for through vehicles along an urban street is the determinant of the operating
LOS. The travel speed along a segment, section or entire length of an urban street is dependent on the
running speed between signalized intersections and the amount of control delay incurred at signalized
LOS A describes primarily free-flow operations. Vehicles are completely unimpeded in their ability to
maneuver within the traffic stream. Control delay at signalized intersections is minimal.
LOS B describes reasonably unimpeded operations. The ability to maneuver within the traffic stream is
only slightly restricted, and control delays at signalized intersections are not significant.
LOS C describes stable operations, however, ability to maneuver and change lanes in midblock location
may be more restricted than at LOS B. Longer queues, adverse signal coordination, or both may
LOS D borders on a range in which in which small increases in flow may cause substantial increases in
delay and decreases in travel speed. LOS D may be due to adverse signal progression, inappropriate
signal timing, high volumes, or a combination of these factors.
LOS E is characterized by significant delays and lower travel speeds. Such operations are caused by a
combination of adverse progression, high signal density, high volumes, extensive delays at critical
LOS F is characterized by urban street flow at extremely low speeds. Intersection congestion is likely at
critical signalized locations, with high delays, high volumes, and extensive queuing.
The methodology to determine LOS stratifies urban streets into four classifications. The classifications
are complex, and are related to functional and design categories. Table A-II describes the functional and
design categories, while Table A-III relates these to the urban street classification.
Once classified, the urban street is divided into segments for analysis. An urban street segment is a
one-way section of street encompassing a series of blocks or links terminating at a signalized
intersection. Adjacent segments of urban streets may be combined to form larger street sections,
provided that the segments have similar demand flows and characteristics.
Levels of service are related to the average travel speed of vehicles along the urban street segment or
Travel times for existing conditions are obtained by field measurements. The maximum-car technique is
used. The vehicle is driven at the posted speed limit unless impeded by actual traffic conditions. In the
maximum-car technique, a safe level of vehicular operation is maintained by observing proper following
distances and by changing speeds at reasonable rates of acceleration and deceleration. The maximum-
car technique provides the best base for measuring traffic performance.
An observer records the travel time and locations and duration of delay. The beginning and ending
points are the centers of intersections. Delays include times waiting in queues at signalized
intersections. The travel speed is determined by dividing the length of the segment by the travel time.
Once the travel speed on the arterial is determined, the LOS is found by comparing the speed to the
criteria in Table A-IV. LOS criteria vary for the different classifications of urban street, reflecting

text.b: Table A-II: Functional and Design Categories for Urban Streets

page.text: Relatively long trips between major points
and through trips entering, leaving, and
Trips of moderate length within relatively

text.b: Table A-III: Urban Street Class based on Function and Design Categories
Table A-IV: Urban Street Levels of Service by Class

page.text: One of the more important elements limiting, and often interrupting the flow of traffic on a highway is
the intersection. Flow on an interrupted facility is usually dominated by points of fixed operation such
as traffic signals, stop and yield signs. These all operate quite differently and have differing impacts on
The capacity of a highway is related primarily to the geometric characteristics of the facility, as well as to
the composition of the traffic stream on the facility. Geometrics are a fixed, or non-varying,
At the signalized intersection, an additional element is introduced into the concept of capacity: time
allocation. A traffic signal essentially allocates time among conflicting traffic movements seeking use of
the same physical space. The way in which time is allocated has a significant impact on the operation of
the intersection and on the capacity of the intersection and its approaches.
LOS for signalized intersections is defined in terms of control delay, which is a measure of driver
discomfort, frustration, fuel consumption, and increased travel time. The delay experienced by a
motorist is made up of a number of factors that relate to control, traffic and incidents. Total delay is the
difference between the travel time actually experienced and the reference travel time that would result
during base conditions, i. e., in the absence of traffic control, geometric delay, any incidents, and any
other vehicles. Specifically, LOS criteria for traffic signals are stated in terms of average control delay
per vehicle, typically for a 15-minute analysis period. Delay is a complex measure and depends on a
number of variables, including the quality of progression, the cycle length, the ratio of green time to
cycle length and the volume to capacity ratio for the lane group.
For each intersection analyzed the average control delay per vehicle per approach is determined for the
peak hour. A weighted average of control delay per vehicle is then determined for the intersection. A
LOS designation is given to the control delay to better describe the level of operation. A description of
levels of service for signalized intersections can be found in Table A-V

text.b: Table A-V: Description of Level of Service for Signalized Intersections

page.text: Very low control delay, up to 10 seconds per vehicle. Progression is extremely favorable, and most
vehicles arrive during the green phase. Many vehicles do not stop at all. Short cycle lengths may tend to
Control delay greater than 10 and up to 20 seconds per vehicle. There is good progression or short cycle
lengths or both. More vehicles stop causing higher levels of delay.
Control delay greater than 20 and up to 35 seconds per vehicle. Higher delays are caused by fair
progression or longer cycle lengths or both. Individual cycle failures may begin to appear. Cycle failure
occurs when a given green phase doe not serve queued vehicles, and overflow occurs. The number of
vehicles stopping is significant, though many still pass through the intersection without stopping.
Control delay greater than 35 and up to 55 seconds per vehicle. The influence of congestions becomes
more noticeable. Longer delays may result from some combination of unfavorable progression, long cycle
lengths, or high volumes. Many vehicles stop, the proportion of vehicles not stopping declines. Individual
Control delay greater than 55 and up to 80 seconds per vehicle. The limit of acceptable delay. High
delays usually indicate poor progression, long cycle lengths, and high volumes. Individual cycle failures are
Control delay in excess of 80 seconds per vehicle. Unacceptable to most drivers. Oversaturation, arrival
flow rates exceed the capacity of the intersection. Many individual cycle failures. Poor progression and
long cycle lengths may also be contributing factors to higher delay.
The use of control delay, which may also be referred to as signal delay, was introduced in the 1997
update to the Highway Capacity Manual, and represents a departure from previous updates. In the third
edition, published in 1985 and the 1994 update to the third edition, delay only included stopped delay.
Thus, the LOS criteria listed in Table A-V differs from earlier criteria.
The current procedures on unsignalized intersections were first introduced in the 1997 update to the
Highway Capacity Manual and represent a revision of the methodology published in the 1994 update to
the 1985 Highway Capacity Manual. The revised procedures use control delay as a measure of
effectiveness to determine LOS. Delay is a measure of driver discomfort, frustration, fuel consumption,
and increased travel time. The delay experienced by a motorist is made up of a number of factors that
relate to control, traffic and incidents. Total delay is the difference between the travel time actually
experienced and the reference travel time that would result during base conditions, i. e., in the absence
of traffic control, geometric delay, any incidents, and any other vehicles. Control delay is the increased
time of travel for a vehicle approaching and passing through an unsignalized intersection, compared with
a free-flow vehicle if it were not required to slow or stop at the intersection.
Two-way stop controlled intersections in which stop signs are used to assign the right-of-way, are the
most prevalent type of intersection in the United States. At two-way stop-controlled intersections the
stop-controlled approaches are referred as the minor street approaches and can be either public streets
or private driveways. The approaches that are not controlled by stop signs are referred to as the major
The capacity of movements subject to delay are determined using the "critical gap" method of capacity
analysis. Expected average control delay based on movement volume and movement capacity is
calculated. A LOS designation is given to the expected control delay for each minor movement. LOS is
not defined for the intersection as a whole. Control delay is the increased time of travel for a vehicle
approaching and passing through a stop-controlled intersection, compared with a free-flow vehicle if it
were not required to slow or stop at the intersection. A description of levels of service for two-way
stop-controlled intersections is found in Table A-VI.

text.b: Table A-VI: Description of Level of Service for Two-Way Stop Controlled Intersections

page.text: Very low control delay less than 10 seconds per vehicle for each movement subject to delay.
Low control delay greater than 10 and up to 15 seconds per vehicle for each movement subject to delay.
Acceptable control delay greater than 15 and up to 25 seconds per vehicle for each movement subject to delay.
Tolerable control delay greater than 25 and up to 35 seconds per vehicle for each movement subject to delay.
Limit of tolerable control delay greater than 35 and up to 50 seconds per vehicle for each movement subject to delay.
Unacceptable control delay in excess of 50 seconds per vehicle for each movement subject to delay.
